'''Matthew and the Mandarins''' are a [[country music]] band from Singapore, active since the 1960s. Among their singles were "[[Singapore Cowboy]]" (1978) and "Let's Put the Sing in Singapore" (1979).

==Background==
Mathew Tan is the leader of the group.<ref>Urbanwire.com, Tue, 22 November 2011 – [https://www.theurbanwire.com/2011/11/meradio-rocks-the-marina-%E2%80%93-not-too-young-not-too-old/ MeRadio Rocks the Marina! – Not too young, not too old – Justine Koh]</ref> The group was formed by Tan under the name Matthew Tan and the Mandarins in 1961. By the mid-1960s, they were appearing in hotels.<ref>Mothership.sg, 22 December 2014 – [https://mothership.sg/2014/12/8-pop-acts-you-boogied-to-if-you-were-alive-in-the-60s/ 8 Pop acts you boogied to if you were alive in the 60s By Joshua Lee]</ref> By the 1970s, as Matthew and the Mandarins, they had achieved a large following. Following their signing to [[EMI]] Singapore in 1978, they performed in Canada, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, Thailand and the United States.<ref>''[[The Straits Times]]'', 15 November 2014 – [http://www.straitstimes.com/lifestyle/entertainment/singapore-cowboy-matthew-tan-riding-high Singapore Cowboy Matthew Tan riding high – Phoebe Low]</ref> They had a number 1 hit with "[[Singapore Cowboy]]".<ref>Bandwagon – [https://www.bandwagon.asia/artists/matthew-the-mandarins Matthew & The Mandarins, Biography]</ref>

One of the venues they played at was the Golden Peacock Lounge at the [[Shangri-la Hotel]]. One of their shows there was watched by Taiwanese singer [[Teresa Teng]].<ref>The Singapore Memory Project – [https://www.singaporememory.sg/data/res19/The_History_in_Matchboxes.pdf The History In Matchboxes Page 4 The Phillumenists]</ref>

The group is mentioned in an ''[[L.A. Weekly]]'' article about L.A. DJ and musician [[Chad Brown (musician)|Chad Brown]] in his quest to find rare and interesting records. Along with a record by the "[[Jose Feliciano]] of Malaysia", Alfred Ho, he rated the Matthew & the Mandarins record as one of his best finds.<ref>''[[L.A. Weekly]]'', 26 November 2010  – [http://www.laweekly.com/music/in-search-of-chad-brown-on-rare-country-from-prison-johnny-paycheck-and-the-{{sic|philli|pines|hide=y}}-2411349 In Search Of: Chad Brown on Rare Country From Prison, Johnny Paycheck and the {{sic|Philli|pines|nolink=y}}, What were your best finds? – Lainna Fader]</ref>

==Career==
===1960s===
The group backed [[Anita Sarawak]] on her ''With a Lot O' Soul'' EP which was released in 1969. The songs were "[[Yesterday's Gone (song)|Yesterday's Gone]]", "[[Where Did Our Love Go]]", "I'm Your Special Fool" and "[[Hi-Heel Sneakers]]".<ref>[[Discogs]] – [https://www.discogs.com/Anita-Sarawak-With-A-Lot-O-Soul/release/4122260  Anita Sarawak – With A Lot O' Soul]</ref>

===1970s===
Matthew and Co. had an LP released on [[Life Records]] in 1974. The album was credited to Mathew with the Mandarins. It featured Matthew Tan on rhythm guitar, Neal Alexander on lead guitar, Richard Danker on bass, piano and organ and Jeffrey Goh on drums and tambourine. Songs on the album included "Louisiana Man", "[[Is Anybody Goin' to San Antone]]", "[[Folsom Prison Blues]]" and "Snakes Crawl at Night".<ref>Discogs – [https://www.discogs.com/Matthew-With-The-Mandarins-Four-Seasons/release/2463004 Matthew With The Mandarins* – Four Seasons]</ref>

In 1978, their self-titled album, ''Matthew & the Mandarins'' was released on EMI EMGS 5016.<ref>''Steve Goodman: Facing the Music'', Clay Eals – [https://books.google.com/books?id=I_lDAQAAIAAJ&q=%22Matthew+%26+the+Mandarins%22 Page 733]</ref> By September that year, the group had sold 5000 copies of their recently cut record. One copy was sent over to the organizers of the [[Tulsa International Festival]]. As a result, the group was invited to go to Oklahoma to take part in the international music festival, held in November that year. The festival which had an attendance of 8000 the previous year had nine countries coming over. In September that year, the group's line-up consisted of Matthew Tan, Michael Png, Derek Danker, Richard Danker and Philip Monteiro.<ref>''New Nation'', Monday 11 September 1978 – [http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/newnation19780911-1.2.88.2 Singapore cowboy hits West, Matthew gets the big invite]</ref>

Their album ''II'' was released in 1979. Produced by Reggie Verghese, it contained some original compositions as well as covers by Tan and Bristow Hopper. Bristow Hopper had in the past worked with [[Roy Orbison]]. The first song on side was "Let's Put the Sing in Singapore". Other songs include covers of [[Kenny Rogers]]' "[[Love or Something Like It (song)|Love or Something Like It]]", [[Kris Kristofferson]]'s "Stranger", [[Johnny Horton]]'s "[[North to Alaska (song)|North to Alaska]]" and the song "Shenandoah". In a 2016 review of the album, some 37 years after its release, Pat Padua of ''Spectrum Culture'' talking about dollar bins being a great place to get acquainted with music from a faraway said it was the kind of dollar bin album that you'd pick up as a joke but turns out to be serious fun.<ref>''Spectrum Culture'', 2 November 2016 – [http://spectrumculture.com/2016/11/02/bargain-bin-babylon-matthew-mandarins-ii/ Bargain Bin Babylon: Matthew and the Mandarins: II – Pat Paduia]</ref><ref>Discogs – [https://www.discogs.com/Matthew-The-Mandarins-II/release/5767315 Matthew* &  The Mandarins – II]</ref> Also in 1979, according to ''[[Billboard Magazine|Billboard]]'' in their 18 August issue, the group was no longer with EMI and they had signed to [[WEA Records|WEA]].<ref>''[[Billboard Magazine|Billboard]]'', 18 August 1979 – [https://books.google.com/books?id=ciQEAAAAMBAJ&dq=%22Matthew+%26+the+Mandarins%22&pg=PT90 Page 59 International Briefs, Singapore Signings]</ref>

===1980s to 1990s===
In 1980, Tan mentioned the problem with pirating. As mentioned in the 16 August issue of ''Billboard'', he said his records had not done as well as expected due to the version by the pirates coming out the day after the official release.<ref>''Billboard'', 16 August 1980 – [https://books.google.com/books?id=lyQEAAAAMBAJ&dq=%22Matthew+Tan%22Singapore&pg=PT71 Page 60 ''Singapore Is Piracy Center, Admits Assn.'' By PETER ONG]</ref>

In 1991, the band was re-formed when Png, the band's former guitar player, suggested Tan to re-form the band.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news |last=Lim |first=Sharon |date=24 October 1991 |title=It’s a little bit of country and rock ’n’ roll with Matthew and The Mandarins |pages=15 |work=Timeszone Central |url=https://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/digitised/article/timeszone19911024-1.2.25.1 |access-date=26 October 2023 |via=[[NewspaperSG]]}}</ref> The re-formed band included Frisco Lim and bassist Eric Tan.<ref name=":0" /> The band added evergreens and rock and roll to their [[repertoire]].<ref name=":0" />

In 1992, EMI released The Very Best of Matthew & the Mandarins which featured "Singapore Cowboy", "Broken lady", "Lucille" and a duet with Sarah Chen, "I Really Don't Want To Know".<ref>National Library Board Singapore – [https://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/music/music/album/5104834d-8a2c-41b1-a00d-65270ec71fb3 The very best of Matthew & the Mandarins, VIEW ALBUM INSERT, 6/6]</ref>

The 27 July 1996 issue of ''Billboard'' noted that EMI had released two compilations by Singaporean act The Quests and an album by Matthew & the Mandarins. EMI Singapore managing director said that there wasn't any plan to re-launch any careers. The albums were just for the fans that remember.<ref>''Billboard'', 27 July 1996 – [https://books.google.com/books?id=xAcEAAAAMBAJ&dq=%22Matthew+%26+the+Mandarins%22&pg=PA59 Page 59 Global Music Pulse, Singapore – Philip Cheah]</ref>

===2000s===
Tan became the subject of ''Singapore Country'', a 2012 documentary by [[Wee Li Lin]] in which the film-maker paid tribute to the song as well as the artist.<ref>''The Straits Times'', 15 November 2014 – [http://www.straitstimes.com/lifestyle/entertainment/singapore-cowboy-matthew-tan-riding-high Singer Matthew Tan will receive a lifetime achievement award for the 1978 country hit song – Phoebe Low]</ref><ref>South East Asia + Indie Films (SINDIE) Saturday, 12 May 2012 – [http://www.sindie.sg/2012/05/singapore-cowboy-more-than-just-pipe.html Singapore Cowboy... more than just a pipe dream]</ref>

On 8 November 2013, The Mandarins were the house band for the Yesterday Once More II concert, held at the Esplanade Concert Hall. Tan was also the musical director of the concert which featured Jimmy Chan, Gina Vadham, Henry Suriya, Hillary Francis, Mel and Joe, and Frank and Robyn.<ref>''[[Today (Singapore newspaper)|Today]]'', 5 November 2013 – [https://www.todayonline.com/entertainment/music/blast-past-spore-veteran-musicians Blast from the past from S’pore veteran musicians ''By'' Christopher Toh]</ref>

In 2014, Tan was appearing at the [[Canberra Country Blues & Roots Festival]]. In addition to playing there, he was one of two artists to receive a Lifetime Achievement Award, the Asia-Pacific Lifetime Achievement Award.<ref>[[Canberra Country Blues & Roots Festival]] – [http://www.canberracountry.com/news.html NEWS 2014, 2. Lifetime Achievement Awards]</ref>

On 4 January 2016 the group performed at a two-concerts event, Coffee Morning & Afternoon Tea, which they performed in the first concert in the morning.<ref>{{Cite web |title=The Best Of Country Hits By Matthew And The Mandarins |url=https://www.bandwagon.asia/gigs/the-best-of-country-hits-by-matthew-and-the-mandarins |access-date=2023-10-26 |website=The Best Of Country Hits By Matthew And The Mandarins {{!}} Bandwagon {{!}} Music media championing and spotlighting music in Asia. |language=en}}</ref>  The group opened with a Johnny Russell composition, "Catfish John". They performed another 18 songs which included a [[Hank Williams]] song " Bayou Country" and the [[Tanya Tucker]] song, "[[Delta Dawn]]". The last song was "Singapore Cowboy" which had the audience incited the audience's approval and had them singing the refrain and requesting an encore.

Along with Leonard and the Country Riders, Ferdinands, Rani Tofani, and country rock group, S.A.L.T, they appeared at the two-day Singapore Country Line Dance Festival 2017 which was held at the Far East Square on a Friday and then on Saturday at the Goodman Arts Centre.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Kaur |first=Gurveen |date=2017-03-10 |title=Yee-Ha! Get in line and dance |language=en |work=The Straits Times |url=https://www.straitstimes.com/lifestyle/entertainment/yee-ha-get-in-line-and-dance |access-date=2023-10-26 |issn=0585-3923}}</ref>

It was announced in ''[[The Straits Times]]'' on 24 April 2017 that the group was one of the acts appearing at the Singapore Expo that month.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Hadi |first=Eddino Abdul |date=2017-04-24 |title=10-hour showcase of local music |language=en |work=The Straits Times |url=https://www.straitstimes.com/lifestyle/10-hour-showcase-of-local-music |access-date=2023-10-26 |issn=0585-3923}}</ref>

==Members==
* Neal Alexander – lead guitar
* Derrick Danker – lead guitar
* Richard Danker – bass, piano, organ
* Jeffrey Goh – drums, tambourine
* Phillip Monteiro – drums
* Michael Png – steel guitar, acoustic guitar
* Matthew Tan – vocals, rhythm guitar
Note: Neal Alexander and Jeffrey Goh only appear on the first album.<ref>Discogs – [https://www.discogs.com/Matthew-The-Mandarins-Matthew-And-The-Mandarins/release/2620266 Matthew* & The Mandarins – Matthew And The Mandarins, Credits ]</ref>
